posts.title: ‚ÄúDid you know...‚Äù about ethnobotany.
posts.description: Ethnobotany studies how cultures have used plants for medicine, food and rituals. Many current remedies come from ancestral knowledge - every plant has a story to discover! üå±üí°

pill.title: CONTENTS
pill.content:
1. Introduction to ethnobotany and its importance in human cultures.
2. The relationship between plants and ancestral civilizations throughout time.
3. The traditional knowledge of indigenous peoples about plants and their use.
4. Medicinal plants: myths, realities and scientific validations.
5. Ethnobotany as a tool for biodiversity conservation.
6. Sacred plants and their role in the rituals of diverse cultures. 
7. The role of shamans and healers in transmitting ethnobotanical knowledge.

pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content: “Did you know that Colombia, one of the most biodiverse countries in the world is home to thousands of plant species with traditional uses documented by indigenous communities?”. Ethnobotany is a fascinating science that studies how people, since ancient times, have used plants in their daily lives: as medicine, food, tools, spiritual symbols and much more. This knowledge has been transmitted orally throughout generations, forming a fundamental part of the cultural identity of indigenous, Afro-descendant and peasant communities in Colombia and Latin America. In this pill, you will discover curiosities, surprising stories and concrete examples of the traditional use of plants in our country, highlighting the connection between nature and culture.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
La etnobotánica es una disciplina científica que combina la botánica con la antropología, enfocándose en cómo las comunidades humanas usan las plantas. Esta ciencia fue impulsada por investigadores como Richard Evans Schultes, considerado el “Padre de la etnobotánica”, quien realizó extensos estudios en la Amazonía colombiana en el siglo XX, documentando el uso de plantas alucinógenas y medicinales por parte de tribus como los Tukano y los Witoto. 
En Colombia, gracias a su ubicación geográfica y diversidad cultural, existe más de 80 grupos étnicos que manejan un vasto conocimiento botánico que aún hoy sigue siendo objeto de estudio. La etnobotánica no solo rescata saberes ancestrales, sin que también promueve el respeto por el patrimonio cultural y biológico de los pueblos.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Pre-Columbian cultures developed complex systems of classification and use of plants that still survive today. For example, the Muiscas used fique to make rope and fabrics, coca for sacred rituals and corn as a central food in their diet. 
In the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, the Kogui and Arhuacos maintain a spiritual vision of the plant world, considering plants as “sisters” that speak, feel and teach. Plants were used not only for their physical properties, but also for their spiritual symbolism: a plant could protect against negative energies, attract good luck or help in making important decisions.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Indigenous communities have a unique worldview that integrates the natural with the spiritual. Each plant has a spirit and a purpose. For example, Yagé (Ayahuasca) is considered by Amazonian peoples as a master plant that teaches and guides through visions. The knowledge of what plant to use, how to prepare it and when to collect it is transmitted through rituals, chants and traditional practices.
In Colombia, more than 6,000 plant species have been documented for traditional use, many of which have not yet been studied by science. This ancestral knowledge is at risk due to the loss of indigenous languages and the westernization of new generations.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Many plants used today in modern medicine were discovered thanks to traditional knowledge. Example:


- Borrachero (Brugmansia): has been used by shamans to induce altered states of consciousness, but also has risks due to its toxicity.
- Aloe Vera: known for its healing and anti-inflammatory properties.
- Chamomile: used for digestive problems and to relieve anxiety.
- Cat's Claw: used in the Amazon, it has shown anti-inflammatory properties that are now being studied in laboratories.
- Quinine: extracted from the bark of the cinchona tree, it is an effective antimalarial.

A common myth is that “if it is natural, it does no harm”, but many plants can be dangerous if not prepared correctly. Today's science is working with communities to validate this knowledge and ensure its safe use.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Colombia is the second most biodiverse country in the world, and much of its flora is found in indigenous and peasant territories. By conserving these territories, the traditional knowledge associated with their plants is also protected. Ethnobotany makes it possible to document this knowledge before it disappears, especially in communities where elders are the sole bearers of knowledge. 
Organizations and universities work with communities to create ethnobotanical gardens, seed banks and environmental education programs. For example, the Ethnobotanical Garden of the SINCHI Institute in Leticia, Amazonas, where more than 200 species used by indigenous peoples are preserved.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Indigenous spirituality is deeply connected to plants. In many cultures, they are considered “spirit beings” that aid in healing and connection with the divine. Coca, sweet yucca and yagé are considered sacred plants in many Colombian communities, used in rituals of initiation, healing or contact with ancestors.
In Kogui rituals, for example, coca leaves are chewed during the “mambeada”, while talking about the harmony of the world. Respect for these plants also involves rituals of planting, care and harvesting with spiritual intention. These practices are being recognized in academic and legal spaces as part of Colombia's intangible cultural heritage.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
In many Colombian communities, knowledge about plants is possessed by elders known as sabedores, curanderos or shamans. These spiritual guides learn from childhood to observe, collect and prepare plants, guided by their dreams, visions and the direct teaching of their elders. In the Uitoto culture, for example, it is considered that a plant must be “requested” from the forest, showing respect and gratitude by collecting it.
The figure of the healer has been stigmatized by modern society, but today there is a movement to revalue this knowledge as a living heritage. The preservation of this knowledge depends on intercultural dialogue and the legal and social recognition of the rights of native peoples.

question.question: Who is considered the ‚ÄúFather of Ethnobotany?

pill.title: CONCLUSIONS
pill.content:
Ethnobotany reminds us that knowledge about plants is not only scientific, but also cultural and spiritual. Through the study of plants and their traditional uses, we better understand the history, medicine and identity of peoples. Preserving this ancestral knowledge is vital to face current challenges such as biodiversity loss and the search for sustainable solutions.
Valuing indigenous wisdom and promoting dialogue between science and tradition opens up new possibilities for a future that is more conscious and respectful of nature.

posts.title: Useful and Common Plants
posts.description: Plants have been fundamental allies in everyday life. From medicinal herbs to essential ingredients in the kitchen, many species provide us with incredible benefits. Discover here some of the most commonly used plants and their multiple uses in health, food and wellness. üå±‚ú®

pill.title: CONTENTS
pill.content:
1. Introduction: the plant wealth of Tame, Yopal and Saravena.
2. The historical relationship of plants with the life of the llanera.
3. Useful plants in medicine, food and construction.
4. Myths and realities about plants in the llanera culture.
5. Conservation of useful species in Casanare and Arauca.
6. Sacred plants: connection between nature and spirituality. 
7. Knowers and guardians: the transmission of knowledge about plants.

pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content:
Colombia is one of the richest countries in biodiversity, and within its regions, the Eastern Plains, where municipalities such as Tame, Yopal and Saravena are located, are home to a variety of plants that have accompanied human life since ancient times.
In these territories, plants have not only been used as food or medicine, but also as construction materials, ritual elements and components of the cultural identity of indigenous people, peasants and wise men.
To learn about these plants is also to understand the history, tradition and present of the region.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Among the main causes of biodiversity loss are fragmentation (loss of continuity of an ecosystem), degradation (loss of natural environmental conditions) and loss of natural connectivity caused by the expansion of the agricultural frontier, changes in land use, deforestation and overexploitation of natural resources. Given this scenario, maintaining ecosystems and the natural connectivity between them becomes an essential task for the conservation of biodiversity and the services it provides.


Among the strategies that Corporinoquia has considered for the conservation of bio-diversity is the creation of protected areas, which must be complemented with specific actions that guarantee the functionality of the landscapes (matrix) in which they are inserted, so that they maintain connectivity and the flow of energy and services, one of these actions are the biological corridors.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
The plain has taught its inhabitants to observe and understand plants as life companions. For example:

- Moriche is not only consumed; in many hamlets its palms are transformed into resistant and cool roofs, ideal for the hot climate of Tame and Saravena.
- The Guásimo is known for its fruits, which when boiled produce a drink that relieves coughs and respiratory infections.
- The Cat's Claw is collected by the wise men of the villages and used as an infusion to strengthen defenses.

In every farm, every road and every path in the plains, there is a plant that is part of daily life, teaching people to live with respect and balance with their environment.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
The knowledge about useful plants does not come from books or laboratories, but from the experience that grandmothers, grandfathers and wise men have accumulated by observing nature. 

Some plants and their traditional uses: 

- Caruto (Genipa americana): its fruits are used as a natural dye for skin and textiles, and its leaves are used in healing infusions.
- Bledo (Amaranthus sp.): its leaves are eaten in stews and soups, and it is known to be nutritious and medicinal.
- Leucaena (Leucaena leucocephala): forage tree that is also a source of organic fertilizer.
- Sarrapia (Dipteryx odorata): a sweet aroma is extracted from the seed, used in perfumery and also in homemade medicines to soothe coughs.

This knowledge is still common in villages, especially in rural areas where the connection with the land is part of daily life.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
In the plain there is a repeated phrase: “if it is bush, it is good and does no harm” - however, not all plants are harmless. For example:

- Borrachero (Brugmansia) is often seen in fences, gardens and yards. Its flowers are showy, but its psychotropic properties can be dangerous if not handled with knowledge.
- Matarratón, although used as a living fence and natural insect repellent, can cause intoxication if improperly prepared for consumption.
- Yopo, a seed used in indigenous rituals, induces deep visions but should only be used under spiritual guidance.

This knowledge is not only tradition, it is also a tool for self-care and survival in rural areas.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Livestock expansion, intensive agriculture and urban growth have reduced the populations of useful plants in Tame, Yopal and Saravena.

However, many initiatives seek to protect them:

- Community and school nurseries, where children and young people learn to plant and care for useful plants.
- Home gardens and model farms, where crops are combined with medicinal and forage plants.
- Programs for the recovery of Morichales and reforestation of riverside areas to protect water sources and biodiversity.

Conserving these plants is key not only to protect nature, but also to keep alive the customs and well-being of the communities.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
In the Eastern Plains, the connection with plants is not only physical, but also spiritual:

- Yopo has been used by peoples such as the Sikuani and Guahibo as a bridge of communication with the world of dreams and the spirit.
- The Moriche, besides being a source of food and material, is called the “tree of life” because the balance of animals, water and human beings depends on it.
- Guayusa and Caruto accompany rituals of initiation, healing and gratitude to nature.

These plants are respected not only for their usefulness but also for their cultural significance.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
The “sabedores” are people who have dedicated their lives to knowing the plants, their cycles and their uses. In farms, roads and villages of Tame, Yopal and Saravena, these people:
- They know in which moon each plant is harvested.
- They know where and when useful species sprout.
- They teach young people and children to respect the natural environment.

They are a living memory that protects a knowledge that not only takes care of people, but also of the land.

question.question: Which of these plants is considered the ‚ÄúTree of Life‚Äù because of its ecological and cultural importance in the Eastern Plains?

pill.title: CONCLUSIONS
pill.content:
Useful plants are part of the essence of life in the plains. To learn about them is to know the roots of Tame, Yopal and Saravena, where nature teaches lessons of respect, wisdom and sustainability every day.
Preserving these plants and their knowledge is to ensure a future where communities and their territories can live in balance.

In this evaluation activity, you must locate the fauna (animals) according to their species group:

posts.title: The alligator toom
posts.description: It tells the story of the caiman toom, an old and gigantic specimen that protects its eggs day and night from the terrible human claws, so that they can know the wonderful life that the tributary of the Orinoco offers them.

posts.title: Mama capybara and the drought of the plains
posts.description: During the year, mother capybara and her children enjoy their life in the vicinity of the Pauto river, but the long arm of pollution and destruction has reached their home, now they must flee and find a new home for their children, lives the story of Capybara mom, our heroine.

pill.title: Mama capybara and the drought of the plains

posts.title: Lola A Mother's Drama
posts.description: Lola, the otter and her children are threatened when a group of animal traffickers arrives on the river bank, who, upon realizing the presence of the otters, see the possibility of selling them to earn money.

posts.title: Super Hero Teddy Anteater
posts.description: "Samy" is a very outgoing anteater who lives happily with his mother but he wants to find new friends so he can have fun in the pond, but this fun is obstructed by the problems that his species and its habitat live due to the evil actions of man. and the monster "petroleum".

posts.title: What are we mom?
posts.description: Faced with the disturbing question of her children, the woolly chucha responds and argues about the identity of their species and the importance they are for the ecosystem.

posts.title: Forest Olympics
posts.description: The story takes place in the forest where all the tapirs once a year met to do their diving competitions and decide who was the best, the winner gave them various seeds to eat and plant and thus counteract the felling of trees.

posts.title: Branches of the trade
posts.description: Yaki is one of the few night monkeys whose family is still complete and reunited; despite the stalking scientists and the continuous fighting between legal and illegal armed groups.

posts.title: Man Stains
posts.description: Othello seems to be used to eating the animals of a nearby farm, the owner although annoying, limits himself to scare him away, but a hunter offers to get rid of the 'problem' at no cost, in the end due to the circumstances the farmer recognizes that it is not the fault of the animal, but of those who invade their environment.

posts.title: No Hunting like at Home
posts.description: Kata is a lonely limpet and with traumas of course abandonment, she was too young to understand the circumstances in which her parents died at the hands of hunters, escaping from one of them she finds her partner and with whom they will persevere so as not to let her your species is eradicated.

posts.title: Slow Leakage, Fast Conclusion
posts.description: We have Roko on the scene, a male long-nosed turtle whose hobby is ... letting time go by. In one of his routines he is found by a group of indigenous people who capture him and reunite with others of the same species. One of them warns him about his destiny: to be merchandise or food.

posts.title: Prejudicial Protection
posts.description: Totema is a cunning, persistent and brave turtle, but that will not reach him until he realizes that his fight has an end.

posts.title: Grandma Goose
posts.description: "Every day an old goose sees how her environment changes, and the poor little geese have to adapt to the changes that damage their ecosystem and their way of life, read the stories of Leonor the older goose."

posts.title: Free-flown
posts.description: Xalma is caged in a truck about to be sold. From her confinement, she tells us her story without suspecting that she will have a positive outcome, although only for her.

posts.title: What Parrots Talk About
posts.description: It tells how an obese parrot got to this condition due to the irresponsible care of human beings. A contradictory way to conserve the species, as deforestation has led these creatures to reduce their numbers.

posts.title: In Other People's Skin
posts.description: Tasko is a pollero wolf, a lizard with a great appetite and a confident character. Initially, he is stressed at the thought that he was abandoned by his family, but he will discover thanks to an old friendship that his children did not leave voluntarily, but instead became articles of clothing and fashion accessories for unconcerned people.

posts.title: Teacher Pepperan
posts.description: "In each school day the teacher Pepperan teleported his students to times ago with his great and funny stories"

posts.title: Road of Roses Glorious Birds
posts.description: It is not enough for this striking specimen called Rozz to stand out, however, of its striking plumage and advantage to find food thanks to its spoon / spatula-shaped beak. but the wild life is raw and he must take it on with his characteristic good attitude.

posts.title: Stolen Thief and his Finished World
posts.description: The soldier garzon is a huge bird whose reputation as a predator is well known among those who have been the victims of its attacks. Iguaro will now discover that while he was stealing prey, he and all the birds were stealing their trees.

pill.title: Stolen Thief and his Finished World

posts.title: Until It's Over
posts.description: A group of deer that feed are ambushed by hunters who set fire to the area to confuse them, in the flight the youngest fall into the hands of men, which forces Azel to return, the young men manage to flee, but Azel stays in his replacement.

posts.title: Red Hot Celebration
posts.description: Ibis is an ordinary corocora, but it knows well what is good for it. When he realizes the evil that humans cause, he decides to simply leave, forming part of the migration statistics that report the red ibis as displaced from its habitat.

posts.title: Before and After, Here There Was a Fish
posts.description: There are no protagonists here, but there are antagonists depending on the point of view. The payara is feared for its ferocity and voracious appetite, but who the real monster is will soon be revealed. Man is killing this species due to overfishing.

pill.title: Before and After, Here There Was a Fish

posts.title: Fruit of the Exploration
posts.description: Some travelers (known as backpackers) get lost in the jungles of the Orinoco and decide to use nearby palms to guarantee survival. In an exaggerated way for narrative sake, they build all kinds of items and prepare some foods. Finally the reflection aims to be responsible and respectful with the use of this plant.

posts.title: Air Oranges
posts.description: There is nothing to worry about, the palo de cruz tree proliferates and its abundance benefits its environment. Polena will limit herself to discovering one of the most remarkable aspects of this species: its reproductive phase, at the end it will throw some pistils into the air inviting them to enjoy this flower.

posts.title: Wood in Ocaso
posts.description: A sad beginning, a knot that does not improve and an ending that gives hope. Logging kills the trees.

posts.title: It goes up like Palma...And there it stays...
posts.description: Here there will only be good omen, abundance and well-being. The corozo palm is a stable species and under good care.

pill.title: It goes up like Palma...And there it stays...

posts.title: Astucia? Pure Straw
posts.description: A plant whose flower pollen does not like? This seems to be the case, since it is a sporiferous plant. But is she bad enough to talk about her?
